list.title: Question 1
list.content: The graph of $y=f(x)$ for $-3\leq x\leq 4$ is shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/0d3ba1ec-6f76-4f87-8209-56090c4506bd/AA1269-q.JPEG) - Write down the value of $f(2)$. [1] Let $g(x)=2f(x)-1$ for $-3\leq x\leq 4$. - On the axes above, sketch the graph of $g$. [2] - Hence determine the value of $(g\circ f)(2) $. [1] - Hence solve the equation $(f\circ g)(x)=0$ when $x>0$. [1]

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Let $f(x) = 2x$, $g(x) = 4x + 6$ and $h(x) = (f\circ g)(x)$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $h(x)$. [2] - Find $h^{-1}(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.3em} h(x) &= (f\circ g)(x) \\[6pt]
  &= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]
  &= f(4x+6) \\[6pt]
  &= 2(4x+6) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8x+12}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we solve the equation $(h\circ h^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = h^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h(h^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
  h(y) &= x \\[12pt]
  8y+12 &= x \\[12pt]
  8y &= x-12 \\[6pt]
  y &= \dfrac{x-12}{8} \hspace{1.3em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{h^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x-12}{8}}
  $$

list.title: Question 3
list.content: The table below shows some values of the domain and range for the function $f(x)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/41870299-38d4-44cf-9ed4-32dbd2e3953e/images/823b37d5-f1dc-4a1f-9675-17cfed71856d/aa1060a.PNG) The graph below shows $y=g(x)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/41870299-38d4-44cf-9ed4-32dbd2e3953e/images/fa9fbb2e-26b0-4247-80c1-dd118b963fcd/aa1060b.PNG) - Evaluate - $f(2)$ - $g(f(2))$ [3] - Find $f^{-1}(g(2))$ [2]

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Let $f(x) = x^3$ and $g(x) = 2x - 1$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $g^{-1}(x)$. [2] - Find $(g\circ f)(x)$. [2] - Solve the equation $(g\circ f)(x) = 0$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
  g(y) &= x \\[12pt]
  2y - 1 &= x \\[12pt]
  2y &= x + 1 \\[6pt]
  y &= \dfrac{x + 1}{2} \hspace{1.9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{g^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x+1}{2}} \hspace{0.6em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (g\circ f)(x) &= g(f(x)) \\[6pt]
  &= g(x^3) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2x^3-1} \hspace{1.1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $(g\circ f)(x) = 0$ for $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.5em} 2x^3-1 &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (b)}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{12.2em} \answer{x \approx 0.794} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Let $f(x) = x^2 + 2$ and $g(x) = x - 3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $f(3)$. [2] - Find $(g\circ f)(3)$. [2] - Find $g^{-1}(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(x) = x^2 + 2$ for $x = 3$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.6em} f(3) &= 3^2 + 2 \\[6pt]
  &= 9 + 2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 11}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $(g\circ f)(x) = g(f(x))$ for $x = 3$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.4em} (g\circ f)(3) &= g(f(3)) \\[6pt]
  &= g(11) \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
  &= 11 - 3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we solve the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[6pt]
  g(y) &= x \\[6pt]
  y - 3 &= x \\[6pt]
  y &= x + 3 \hspace{2.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{g^{-1}(x) = x+3} \hspace{0.8em}
  $$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Let $f(x) = 4x - 3$ and $g(x) = 2x$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Write down the value of $g(5)$. [1] - Find $(f\circ g)(x)$. [2] - Find $(f\circ g)^{-1}(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{g(5) = 10}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (f\circ g)(x) &= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]
  &= f(2x) \\[6pt]
  &= 4(2x) - 3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8x - 3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $h(x) = (f\circ g)(x)$.
Hence $h^{-1}(x) = (f\circ g)^{-1}(x)$.
  If we solve the equation $(h\circ h^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = h^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h(h^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
  h(y) &= x \\[12pt]
  8y - 3 &= x \\[12pt]
  8y &= x + 3 \\[6pt]
  y &= \dfrac{x + 3}{8} \hspace{1.8em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{(f\circ g)^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x + 3}{8}} \hspace{2.7em}
  $$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Let $f(x)=4x-2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - The graph of a linear function $g$ is perpendicular to the graph of $f$ and passes through the origin. Find an expression for $g(x)$.[2] - The graph of a linear function $h$ is parallel to the graph of $f$ and passes through the point $(3,4)$. Find an expression for $h(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- The slope of $f$ is $m_f=4$, then $m_g=-\dfrac{1}{4}$ is the slope of the function $g$ that is perpendicular to $f$, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y-y_1&=m(x-x_1)\\[6pt]
   y-0&=-\dfrac{1}{4}(x-0)\\[6pt]
   y&=-\dfrac{1}{4}x
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore, $\tcbhighmath{g(x)=-\dfrac{1}{4}x}.$
- The slope of the function $h$ is $m_h=4$ because $h$ is parallel to the graph $f$. We have,

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y-y_1=m(x-x_1)\\[6pt]
  y-4&=4(x-3)\\[6pt]
  y-4&=4x-12\\[6pt]
  y=4x-8
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore, $\tcbhighmath{h(x)=4x-8}.$

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Consider the line $L_1$ which passes through the points $A (-4,-4)$ and $B(8,-1)$. - Find the gradient of the line $L_1$. [1] Line $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through the point $(-a,2a)$ where $a \in \mathbb{R}$. - Given that $L_2$ intersects the $y$-axis at $y=2a-3$, find the value of $a$. [3]

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Let $f(x) = (x+2)^3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [3] Let $g$ be a function so that $(f\circ g)(x) = 27x^6$. - Find $g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[7pt]
  f(y) &= x \\[6pt]
  (y+2)^3 &= x \\[6pt]
  y+2 &= \sqrt[3]{x} \\[6pt]
  y &= \sqrt[3]{x} - 2 \hspace{1.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.3em} \answer{f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]{x} - 2}
  $$

- If we solve the equation $(f\circ g)(x) = 27x^6$ for $y = g(x)$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(g(x)) &= 27x^6 \\[6pt]
  f(y) &= 27x^6 \\[6pt]
  (y+2)^3 &= 27x^6 \\[6pt]
  y+2 &= 3x^2 \\[6pt]
  y &= 3x^2 - 2 \hspace{0.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.5em} \answer{g(x) = 3x^2 - 2}
  $$

list.title: Question 10
list.content: The equation of a line $L_1$ is $2x + 3y = -5$. - Find the gradient of $L_1$. [2] A second line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$. - State the gradient of $L_2$. [1] The point P$(4,0)$ lies on $L_2$. - Find the equation of $L_2$, giving your answer in the form $ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$. [2] The point Q is the intersection of $L_1$ and $L_2$. - Find the coordinates of Q. [3]
list.markScheme:
- If we rewrite the equation of $L_1$ in the form $y = mx + c$, we
have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2x + 3y &= -5 \\[12pt]
  3y &= -2x - 5 \\[6pt]
  y &= -\dfrac{2}{3}x-\dfrac{5}{3} \hspace{0.4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the gradient of $L_1$ is
$\answer{m_{L_1} = -\dfrac{2}{3}}$
- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{(-2/3)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{3}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with P$(4,0)$ and $m = 3/2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[5pt]
  y - 0 &= \dfrac{3}{2}\hspace{0.05em}(x - 4) \\[6pt]
  2y &= 3x - 12 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.45em} \answer{0 = 3x - 2y - 12}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L_1&:\hspace{1.0em} 2x + 3y = -5 \hspace{3em}{(1)} \\[6pt]
  L_2&:\hspace{1.0em} 3x - 2y = 12 \hspace{3.25em}{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving
the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $x$ and $y$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{-0.8em} \begin{array}{rcl}
  x &=& 2 \\[6pt]
  y &=& -3
  \end{array}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(2,-3)}$

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Let $f(x) = \sqrt{x+7}$, for $x \geq -7$. - Find $f^{-1}(3)$. [3] Let $g$ be a function such that $g^{-1}$ exists for all real numbers. - Given that $g(9) = 4$, find $(f\circ g^{-1})(4)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(3) = 3$ for
$y = f^{-1}(3)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(3)) &= 3 \hspace{3.8em} \\[6pt]
  f(y) &= 3 \\[4pt]
  \sqrt{y + 7} &= 3 \\[6pt]
  y + 7 &= 9 \\[6pt]
  y &= 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{f^{-1}(3) = 2} \hspace{2.4em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  4 &= g(9) \\[6pt]
  g^{-1}(4) &= g^{-1}(g(9)) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{11em} g^{-1}(4) &= 9 \hspace{3.5em} [\text{since $(g^{-1}\hspace{-0.1em}\circ g)(9) = 9$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (f\circ g^{-1})(4) &= f(g^{-1}(4)) \hspace{0.9em} \\[8pt]
  &= f(9) \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{9+7} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{16} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Let $f(x) = \sqrt{x-3}$, for $x \geq 3$. - Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [2] Let $g(x) = x^2 +1$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $(g\circ f)(28)$. [2] - Write down the range of: - $f^{-1}$; - $g$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[7pt]
  f(y) &= x \\[5pt]
  \sqrt{y - 3} &= x \\[6pt]
  y - 3 &= x^2 \\[6pt]
  y &= x^2 + 3 \hspace{1.7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{f^{-1}(x) = x^2 + 3} \hspace{0.4em}
  $$

- Evaluating $f(x) = \sqrt{x - 3}$ for $x = 28$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1em} f(28) &= \sqrt{28-3} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{25} \\[8pt]
  &= 5\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (g\circ f)(28) &= g(f(28)) \\[7pt]
  &= g(5) \\[6pt]
  &= 5^2 +1 \hspace{2.2em} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= 26} \end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{[3,\infty)}$
  - $\answer{[1,\infty)}$

list.title: Question 13
list.content: Let $f(x) = x^3 + 1$ and $g(x) = x-2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $f(2)$. [2] - Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [2] - Solve $(f\circ g)(x) = 0$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(x) = x^3 + 1$ for $x = 2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} f(2) &= 2^3 + 1 \\[6pt]
  &= 8 + 1 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 9}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for $y = f^{-1}(x)$,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.6em} f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[6pt]
  f(y) &= x \\[6pt]
  y^3 + 1 &= x \\[6pt]
  y^3 &= x - 1 \\[5pt]
  y &= \sqrt[3]{x-1} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2em} \answer{f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]{x-1}}
  $$

- Solving the equation $(f\circ g)(x) = 0$ for $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(g(x)) &= 0 \\[7pt]
  f(x-2) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \hspace{4.6em} (x-2)^3 + 1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x-2 &= \sqrt[3]{-1} \hspace{3em} [=-1] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.7em} \answer{x = 1}
  $$

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Let $f(x) = 0.2e^{x+2} - 4$, for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$. - On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/4d1c7bf9-8d2a-4f7a-945e-f582b73039b2/219ede634589aee775d4d590dd79b30ff5c63914.svg) - Find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [2] The graph of $f$ is reflected in the $x$-axis, then translated 1 unit in the direction of the positive $x$-axis and 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis to obtain the graph of a function $g$. - Find $g(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $y = f(x)$ for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/0c8cb343-6319-4c4b-bd01-6881dfb5c2ff/a0ce7feb5a9182c2d088b3711cfba75a324b8033.svg)


- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.2em} 0.2e^{x+2} - 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &\approx 0.996 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$\answer{(0.996,0)}$
  - Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
    &= 0.2e^{0+2} - 4 \hspace{0.4em} \\[7pt]
    &\approx -2.52\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$\answer{(0,-2.52)}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.5em} g(x) &= -f(x-1) + 2 \\[6pt]
  &= -\big[0.2e^{(x-1)+2} - 4\big] + 2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -0.2e^{x+1} + 6}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 15
list.content: The following diagram shows the graph of $y = f(x)$, for $-4 \leq x \leq 5$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c34c19d0-884e-4539-a819-e275c2b0d6d7/images/663b2cb7-2f4f-4aae-ac6f-66128af5d430/8dc73726e7704b5f5e31e8ab0e8d2ebbdc109321.svg) - Write down the value of: - $f(1)$; - $f^{-1}(2)$. [2] - Find the domain of $f^{-1}$. [2] - Sketch the graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ on the same grid above. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{f(1) = 3}$
  - $\answer{f^{-1}(2) = 0}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{domain of $f^{-1}$} &= \text{range of $f$} \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= [-2,4]}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ is a reflection of the graph of
$y = f(x)$ across the line $y = x$.
  Hence, if we sketch the graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ on the same grid
below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c34c19d0-884e-4539-a819-e275c2b0d6d7/images/ed275ec0-9181-4d08-8b91-8ecbfeaad85a/90bb640268e36201860be09ad192280e600a64a2.svg)

list.title: Question 16
list.content: - Express $2x^2 - 8x + 9$ in the form $a(x+b)^2 + c$ where $a,b,c \in\mathbb{Z}$. [2] - Given that $f(x) = x - 2$ and $(g\circ f)(x) = 2x^2 - 8x + 9$, find $g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the method of completing the square, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2x^2 - 8x + 9 &= 2\big[x^2 - 4x\big] + 9 \\[6pt]
  &= 2\big[(x-2)^2 - 4\big] + 9 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  &= 2(x-2)^2 - 8 + 9 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2(x-2)^2 + 1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.3em} (g\circ f)(x) &= 2x^2 - 8x + 9 \\[6pt]
  g(f(x)) &=  2(x-2)^2 + 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
  g(x-2) &= 2(x-2)^2 + 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(x) = x - 2$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{g(x) = 2x^2 + 1} \hspace{3.4em}
  $$

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2}$, for $x > -2$. The diagram below shows part of the graph of $f$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ca4f0d8-2c1b-4539-b90a-140704aebde0/images/41cb6db4-c952-44a9-a5d0-dc5fd6907d15/0b26b0e195f4a087c10216491d624f903712efff.svg) - Find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [2] - Find the equation of the vertical asymptote to the graph of $f$. [2] - Find the area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the $x$-axis and the $y$-axis. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.8em} \dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2} &= 0 \\[4pt]
    x &= -1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$\answer{(-1,0)}$
  - Evaluating $f(x)=\dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2}$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.4em} f(0) &= \dfrac{\ln 2}{2} \\[8pt] 
    &\approx 0.347\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$\answer{(0,0.347)}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \rightarrow 0^+} \ln x &= -\infty \hspace{3em} \\[7pt]
  \lim_{x \rightarrow -2^+} \ln (x+2) &= -\infty \\[6pt]
  \lim_{x \rightarrow -2^+} f(x) &= -\infty \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence
the equation of the vertical asymptote is
$\answer{x = -2}$
- The area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the $x$-axis
and the $y$-axis is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10em} A &= \int_{-1}^0 \dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2}\,\mathrm{d}x \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.193 \text{ units}^2} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 18
list.content: Let $f(x) = e^x - 2$ and $g(x) = 3x + k$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $k$ is a constant. - Find $(g\circ f)(x)$. [2] - Given that $\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} (g\circ f)(x) = -4$, find the value of $k$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.8em} (g\circ f)(x) &= g(f(x)) \\[6pt]
  &= g(e^x - 2) \\[6pt]
  &= 3(e^x - 2) + k \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 3e^x - 6 + k}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} (g\circ f)(x) &= -4 \hspace{6.9em} \\[4pt]
  \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty}\hspace{-0.2em}\big[3e^x - 6 + k\big] &= -4 \\[4pt]
  3(0) - 6 + k &= -4 \\[9pt]
  - 6 + k &= -4 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.2em} \answer{k = 2}
  $$

list.title: Question 19
list.content: The following diagram shows the graph of $y = f(x)$, for $-1 \leq x \leq 2$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8407806b-3c8d-4f8a-ba57-52619272880d/images/ee08b3c6-49a0-41f7-814f-bb4d9079b11c/ccc9d5942ccfefc2e6313a34922fed1ada13594f.svg) - Write down the value of: - $f(1)$; - $f^{-1}(-2)$. [2] - Find $(f\circ f)(1)$. [2] - Sketch the graph of $y = f(-x)$ on the same grid above. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{f(1) = 2}$
  - $\answer{f^{-1}(-2) = -1}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (f\circ f)(1) &= f(f(1)) \\[6pt]
  &= f(2) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 6}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The graph of $y = f(-x)$ is a reflection of the graph of $y = f(x)$
in the $y$-axis.
  Hence, if we sketch the graph of $y = f(-x)$ on the same grid below,
we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8407806b-3c8d-4f8a-ba57-52619272880d/images/64f14811-163b-49f4-8bcc-e95f5b9a1d96/d2b3518aa3484d1ffd19b0a1dd3f20d6f92c6046.svg)

list.title: Question 20
list.content: Two functions, $f$ and $g$, are defined in the following table. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a18c1edb-e266-48ea-9409-91450ee6259e/images/72fb6a0c-ca68-40db-a765-15cc4604525e/f16cb92d520a6fc6d08cc849fc6b256348e1335f.svg) - Write down the value of $f(2)$. [1] - Find the value of $(g\circ f)(2)$. [2] - Find the value of $g^{-1}(5)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{f(2) = 0}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (g\circ f)(2) &= g(f(2)) \\[6pt]
  &= g(0) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (g\circ g^{-1})(5) &= 5 \hspace{3.7em} \\[6pt]
  g(g^{-1}(5)) &= 5 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{9.7em} \answer{g^{-1}(5) = -4} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $g(-4) = 5$}]
  $$

list.title: Question 21
list.content: The functions $f$ and $g$ are defined such that $f(x) = \dfrac{x-2}{3}$ and $g(x) = 12x+4$. - Show that $(g\circ f)(x) = 4x-4$. [2] - Given that $(g\circ f)^{-1}(a) = 10$, find the value of $a$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.8em} (g\circ f)(x) &= g\hspace{0.05em}(f(x)) \\[9pt]
  &= g\Big(\dfrac{x-2}{3}\Big) \\[5pt]
  &= 12\Big(\dfrac{x-2}{3}\Big)+4 \\[9pt]
  &= 4\hspace{0.05em}(x-2) + 4 \\[13pt]
  &= 4x-4\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.25em} (g\circ f)^{-1}(a) &= 10 \\[6pt]
  (g\circ f)(10) &= a \\[6pt]
  4(10)-4 &= a \hspace{3em} [\text{by part $(a)$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{a = 36}
  $$

list.title: Question 22
list.content: The area, $A$, of a given square can be represented by the function $$ \begin{aligned} A(P) &= \dfrac{P^2}{16}, \hspace{0.5em} P \geq 0,\end{aligned} $$ where $P$ is the perimeter of the square. The graph of the function $A$, for $0 \leq P \leq 20$, is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/46346d59-3adc-4e1d-9102-a09321b02eea/images/ff39b657-e430-4f20-b9ef-fcc41c30e921/8c2c1a298c1b79e92e64f94fe2b4a4d452e488ad.svg) - Find the value of $A(20)$. [1] - On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $A^{-1}$. [3] - In the context of the question, explain the meaning of $A^{-1}(4) = 8$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $A(P)$ for $P = 20$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  A(P) &= \dfrac{20^2}{16} \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 25}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $A^{-1}$, on the grid
below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/46346d59-3adc-4e1d-9102-a09321b02eea/images/1a31c9ea-d742-4abc-b00b-5af09583611b/508588bd8662a40575516587374d1e3379be6249.svg)


- $\answer{\text{For a given square, when the area is \(4\), the perimeter is \(8\)}}$

list.title: Question 23
list.content: - Express $3x^2 + 18x + 20$ in the form $a(x+b)^2 + c$ where $a,b,c \in\mathbb{Z}$. [2] - Given that $f(x) = x + 3$ and $(g\circ f)(x) = 3x^2 + 18x + 20$, find $g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the method of completing the square, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  3x^2 + 18x + 20 &= 3\big[x^2 + 6x\big] + 20 \\[6pt]
  &= 3\big[(x+3)^2 - 9\big] + 20 \\[6pt]
  &= 3(x+3)^2 - 27 + 20 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 3(x+3)^2 - 7}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10.8em} (g\circ f)(x) &= 3x^2 + 18x + 20 \\[6pt]
  g(f(x)) &= 3(x+3)^2 - 7 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
  g(x+3) &= 3(x+3)^2 - 7 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(x) = x + 3$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{g(x) = 3x^2 - 7} \hspace{0.6em}
  $$

list.title: Question 24
list.content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = \sqrt[3]{2x+1}$, for $-14 \leq x \leq 13$. - Write down the range of $f$. [2] - Find an expression for $f^{-1}$. [2] - Write down the domain and range of $f^{-1}$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have
1 $f$ is continuous and increasing;
  2 $f(-14) = -3$ and $f(13) = 3$.
  Hence the range of $f$ is
$\answer{[-3,3]}$
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[13pt]
  f\left(y\right) &= x \\[12pt]
  \sqrt[3]{2y+1} &= x \\[12pt]
  2y+1 &= x^3 \\[6pt]
  y &= \dfrac{x^3 - 1}{2} \hspace{1.3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence an
expression for $f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x^3 - 1}{2}}$
- The domain and range of $f^{-1}$ are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{domain}: & \hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{[-3,3]} \\[8pt]
  \text{range}: & \hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{[-14,13]}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 25
list.content: The function $f$ is given by $f(x) = \dfrac{4x^2 - 128}{x^2 - 16}$, for $x \neq \pm 4$. - Prove that $f$ is an even function. [2] - - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Write down the range of $f$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- For any $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \neq \pm 4$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-x) &= \dfrac{4(-x)^2 - 128}{(-x)^2 - 16} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{4x^2 - 128}{x^2 - 16} \\[12pt]
  &= f(x)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $f$ is an even function.
- 
  - If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4b2579c-edb3-474f-9012-eba8d8995131/images/99bd6e4e-6a5d-4072-8d6f-a53d9d744a19/6c198522156a50253fdb14e877863a1523046369.svg)


  - $\answer{(-\infty,4) \cup [8,\infty)}$

list.title: Question 26
list.content: The ocean pressure, $P$, under sea level can be modelled by the function $$ P(D) = \dfrac{D}{10}+1 $$ where $D$ is the distance in metres below sea level and $P$ is measured in atmospheres. A submarine cruising near the surface is submerged according to the function $$ D(t) = 10+5t $$ where $t$ is measured in minutes and $D$ is the distance the submarine is below sea level, measured in metres. - Find the composite function $P\circ D$ and explain what it means in the context of this question[3] - Find and interpret $(P\circ D)(10)$.[2]

list.title: Question 27
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{4}x^2 - 2$ and $g(x) = x^2 - 4$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Show that $(f\circ g)(x) = \dfrac{1}{4}x^4 - 2x^2 + 2$. [2] - On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y = (f \circ g)(x)$, for $0 \leq x \leq 3$. [3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c14b02c2-8458-4f34-a816-a5c569f5f2fc/images/ceb2f6e6-5725-4682-8f4f-1fb5b9e8117e/b4ef7d37b745cb564b996b9d79dff67b636cf799.svg) - The equation $(f\circ g)(x) = k$ has exactly two solutions, for $0 \leq x \leq 3$. Find the possible values of $k$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (f\circ g)(x) &= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]
  &= f(x^2 - 4) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{3em} &= \dfrac{1}{4}(x^2 - 4)^2 - 2 \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{4}(x^4 - 8x^2+16) - 2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{4}x^4 - 2x^2 + 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $y = (f \circ g)(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c14b02c2-8458-4f34-a816-a5c569f5f2fc/images/3cea73bc-198a-4cce-8863-df5d6b4c9bb7/35e596bf685bd72ab7dad8286b0830ba0c592c52.svg)


- The line $y = k$ intersects the graph of $y = (f \circ g)(x)$
exactly at two points when $-2 < k \leq 2$.
  Hence the equation $(f \circ g)(x) = k$ has exactly two solutions
when  $\answer{-2 < k \leq 2}$

list.title: Question 28
list.content: A tyre manufacturing company has found that the number of tyres it produces, $N$, can be modelled by the function $$ N(t)=3t-9 $$ where $t$ is the number of hours the factory operates per day, with a minimum of 3 hours. The profit the company makes, $P$, in dollars, depends on the number of tyres produced, and is modelled by the function $$ P(N)=60N-850 $$ where $N$ is the number of tyres produced. - Find the company's profit or loss if it operates for $6$ hours per day.[2] - Find the company's profit in terms of the hours of operation per day, $t$.[2] - Determine the number of hours the company needs to operate the factory per day in order to earn a positive profit. Give your answer to the nearest hour.[2]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $t=6$ in $N(t)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N(6) &= 3(6)-9 = 9\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Thus, the profit is given by P(9)

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
   P(9) &= 60(9)-850 = -310
   \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, operating $6$
hours a day, the company has a loss:
$\answer{\$\hspace{0.07em}-310}$
- The profit in terms of the hours of operation per day can be found
by the composite function $P\circ N$. Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ N)(t) &= P(N(t)) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= P(3t-9) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
  &= 60(3t-9)-850\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
  &\hspace{-5em}\answer{(P\circ N)(t) = 180\hspace{0.05em}t-1390}\hspace{5em}{(1)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The company has a positive profit if (1) is greater than 0. Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ N)(t) &>0\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  180t-1390 &> 0 \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  t &> \dfrac{1390}{180} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  t &> 7.72.\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, the
factory needs to operate
$\answer{8}$
hours per day in order for the company to earn a positive profit.

list.title: Question 29
Question 30
list.content: The circumference, $C$, of a given circle can be represented by the function $$ \begin{aligned} C(A) &= 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{A}{\pi}}, \hspace{0.5em} A \geq 0,\end{aligned} $$ where $A$ is the area of the circle. The graph of the function $C$, for $0 \leq A \leq 24$, is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f456fc19-890c-4269-962e-6613e63c4f7d/images/1e281987-3b8b-4dcc-809b-86850ebedbb5/3388e210bb4d6f02426816cb2651396f2822c4c1.svg) - Find the value of $C(24)$. [1] - On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $C^{-1}$. [3] - In the context of the question, explain the meaning of $C^{-1}(2\pi) = \pi$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $C(A)$ for $A = 24$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  C(A) &= 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{24}{\pi}} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 17.4}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $C^{-1}$, on the grid
below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f456fc19-890c-4269-962e-6613e63c4f7d/images/4d19e261-35fc-454f-b0a3-35e2cd9aa8c3/fae26733051cc1a7c15c3478abb0d0697e69d7fa.svg)


- $\answer{\text{For a given circle, when the circumference is \(2\pi\), the area is \(\pi\)}}$

list.title: Question 31
list.content: A town is planning to construct a jogging path in a grass field $170$ m long and $70$ m wide. The path is to be the shape of a rectangle with two semicircles of radius $x$, as shown in the diagram. The sides of the rectangle connecting the circles are to be $100$ m long. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/65b7adec-96d0-405d-bd92-b10fc425e8d5/images/8c94d818-8318-43d4-a5bd-1126ae8aab6c/22448faee8b9c6574b3fdefa8505f67030a94583.svg) - Write down a function, $P$, (in metres) for the perimeter of the jogging path, in terms of the radius, $x$.[1] - Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the dimensions of the grass field.[2] - Find an equation for the inverse function $P^{-1}(x)$. Express your answer in the form $P^{-1}(x)=mx+c$.[2] The designers of the path are deciding whether the total length of the path should be $300$ m, $400$ m, or $500$ m. The designers want to maximise the perimeter of the path, but fit the path in the grass field. - Determine which length is most suitable, given the dimensions of the grass field.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The perimeter for the path is the sum of the two straight sides
connecting the circles and the perimeter of a complete circle of
radius $x$. We get

  $$
  \answer{P(x) = 200+2\pi x}
  $$

- The length of the path will be $100+2x$ and its width $2x$.
Therefore we require $100+2x\leq 170$ and $2x\leq 70$. Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Domain: } 0 < x \leq 35.}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  For
the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=200$ and
$P(35)=200+70\pi$. We get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Range: } 200\leq P(x) \leq 200+70\pi.}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 200+2\pi x\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  x &= 200+2\pi y\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  y &= \dfrac{x-200}{2\pi}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\ 
  &\hspace{-3.2em}\answer{P^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{1}{2\pi}x - \dfrac{100}{\pi}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P^{-1}(P)$, then the length and width of the running
track can be calculated, as shown in the following table.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/65b7adec-96d0-405d-bd92-b10fc425e8d5/images/282aeb49-7c34-4d6f-82ac-e270f942f1f3/8985560368df68be350c8eca5afbe5b19a733963.svg)


  From the table, we can see that the largest perimeter of the options
that still fit inside the grass field dimensions is

  $$
  \answer{P=400\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}.}
  $$

list.title: Question 32
list.content: Harry is planning on constructing a glass window in one of the outer walls of his house. The dimensions of the wall space available are 2m x 2m. Harry wants the window to be in the shape shown in the diagram below. The bottom section is a rectangle and the top part is a semicircle of radius $x$ m. Harry wants the height of the rectangle to be fixed at 1 m. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bbc6b0f-8f28-44ce-aae9-1a77840548c5/images/1970cc7c-4fb4-47c4-8b78-0b174bc78816/4b81f49038bd3a70fed3ed55e752da67f426bdf2.svg) - Write down a function $P$ (in metres) for the perimeter of the window in terms of the radius, $x$.[1] - Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the dimensions of the available wall.[2] - Find an equation for the inverse function $P^{-1}(x)$.[2] Harry wants to maximise the size of the window, however the window frame that covers the perimeter of the window can only be 5, 6, or 7 metres long, due to manufacturing restrictions. - Determine which perimeter length is the best option for Harry.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The perimeter for the window is the sum of the three sides of the
rectangle and the semicircle, thus we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(x) &= \text{Rectangle width}+2\times\text{Rectangle height}+\text{Semicircle} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= 2x+2(1)+\dfrac{\cancel{2}\pi x}{\cancel{2}} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  &\hspace{-2.15em}\answer{P(x) = 2+(2+\pi)x}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The width of the window will be $2x$ and the height $1+x$.
Therefore, we require $2x\leq 2$ and $1+x\leq 2$.
Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Domain: } 0\leq x \leq 1.}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Now
for the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=2$ and
$P(1)=4+\pi$. Therefore,

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Range: } 2\leq P(x) \leq 4+\pi.}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 2+(2+\pi)x\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  x &= 2+(2+\pi)y\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  y &= \dfrac{x-2}{(2+\pi)}\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\ 
  &\hspace{-3.2em}\answer{P^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x-2}{(2+\pi)}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P^{-1}(P)$, then the length and width of the window
can be calculated, as shown in the following table
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bbc6b0f-8f28-44ce-aae9-1a77840548c5/images/2db4d8fa-3dad-4595-94a4-c7663a5dbf7c/95900dceeb57876cf3bec3ce67dc138811471933.svg)


  From the table, we can see that the perimeter that maximizes the
dimension of the window that fits in the wall is

  $$
  \answer{P=7\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}.}
  $$

list.title: Question 33
list.content: The function $f$ is defined as $f(x)=3e^{\frac{x}{2}}$ where $x \in \mathrm{R}$ and is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e175b6d9-563c-4c8f-a8fa-b8e3ca7ce99f/images/b05207b3-e706-477a-85d6-ff97ee420070/AA1180_q.JPEG) - Write down the equation of the asymptote of $f(x)$. [1] - Write down the $y-$intercept of $f(x)$. [1] - Hence, or otherwise, sketch the inverse of $f(x)$ on the image above. Make sure any asymptotes and/or intercepts are clearly marked. [2] - Determine the domain of the inverse of $f(x)$. [1]

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined as $f(x) = \sqrt{\dfrac{6+2x}{6-2x}}$, for
$-3 \leq x < 3$.
Find the inverse function of $f$, stating its domain and range.
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for $y = f^{-1}(x)$,
we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[16pt]
f(y) &= x \\[11pt]
\sqrt{\dfrac{6+2y}{6-2y}} &= x \\[6pt]
\dfrac{6+2y}{6-2y} &= x^2 \\[12pt]
6 + 2y &= 6x^2-2x^2y \\[16pt]
3 + y &= 3x^2-x^2y \\[16pt]
(x^2 + 1)y &= 3x^2 - 3 \\[12pt]
y &= \dfrac{3x^2 - 3}{x^2 + 1} \hspace{3em}  \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the
inverse function of $f$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) =  \dfrac{3x^2 - 3}{x^2 + 1}}$
The domain of $f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{[0,\infty)}$
and range of $f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{[-3,3)}$

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
The following diagram shows the graph of $y = f(x)$. The graph has a
horizontal asymptote at $y = -2$. The graph crosses the $x$-axis at
$x = -2$ and $x = 2$, and the $y$-axis at $y = 2$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/310719d6-0a51-417e-9742-470a2dcd6bc2/images/1ada7a4a-0845-436d-8d28-d7890e589b6b/c78f9f086a8acc010784a1b850302f69d14d6493.svg)


On the following set of axes, sketch the graph of $y = [f(x)]^2-1$,
clearly showing any asymptotes with their equations and the coordinates
of any local maxima or minima.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/310719d6-0a51-417e-9742-470a2dcd6bc2/images/f597f133-d069-41e9-a5ed-59badeaee8c4/188aa0d6105478da37f4d68a7d60a3e5ae3b83f9.svg)
list.markScheme:
We have

list.title: Question 36
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$, for $x \neq -1$. - For the graph of $f$, find: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept; - the equation of the vertical asymptote. [5] Let $g(x) = x-3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. The graphs of $f$ and $g$ intersect at points A and B. - Find the coordinates of A and B. [5] - Find the equation of the straight line that passes through A and B, giving your answer in the form $y = mx + c$. [3] - Write down the gradient of the line that is perpendicular to the line passing through A and B. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Since the equation $f(x) = 0$ has no solutions, there are
$\answer{\text{no \(x\)-intercepts}}$
  - Evaluating $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(0) &= \dfrac{5}{0+1} \hspace{3.6em} \\[6pt]
    &= 5\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $y$-intercept is
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,5)}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
    x+1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= -1\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$\answer{x = -1}$

- Solving the equation $f(x) = g(x)$ for $x$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \dfrac{5}{x+1} &= x-3 \\[6pt]
  5 &= (x+1)(x-3) \\[9pt]
  5 &= x^2 - 2x - 3 \\[9pt]
  0 &= x^2 - 2x - 8 \\[10pt]
  0 &= (x+2)(x-4) \\[10pt]
  x &= -2,\hspace{0.25em}4 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $g(x) = x-3$
for $x = -2$ and $x = 4$, we find

  $$
  \hspace{3.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  y &=& g(-2) &=& -5 \\[9pt]
  y &=& g(4) &=& 1
  \end{array}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{\mathrm{A}(-2,-5)}$
and
$\answer{\mathrm{B}(4,1)}$
- Using the gradient formula with A$(-2,-5)$ and B$(4,1)$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{\mathrm{AB}} &= \dfrac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1-(-5)}{4-(-2)} \\[10pt]
  &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
A$(-2,-5)$ and $m = 1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{0.15em} y - (-5) &= (1)(x-(-2)) \\[6pt]
  y + 5 &= x + 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{y = x-3} \hspace{0.15em}
  $$

- $\answer{m_{\perp\mathrm{AB}} = -1}$

list.title: Question 37
list.content: Consider the function $f(x) = x^2\arcsin(x)$, for $-1 \leq x \leq 1$. - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [3] - Write down the range of $f$. [2] - Solve the inequality $\left|x^2\arcsin(x)\right| > 0.5$. [3]

list.title: Question 38
list.content: - Write down the domain and range of the logarithmic function $y = \log_a x$ where $a > 0$ and $a \neq 1$. [2] - Given that $\log_{x^2} y = 9 \log_y (x^2)$, find all the possible expressions of $y$ as a function of $x$. [6]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{domain}:\hspace{0.75em}&\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(0,\infty)} \hspace{1.8em} \\[8pt]
  \text{range}:\hspace{0.75em}&\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\mathbb{R}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_{x^2} y &= 9 \log_y (x^2) \\[11pt]
  \hspace{4em} \dfrac{\ln y}{\ln (x^2)} &= \dfrac{9\ln (x^2)}{\ln y} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{\ln y}{2\ln x} &= \dfrac{18\ln x}{\ln y} \\[12pt]
  (\ln y)^2 &= (6\ln x)^2 \\[16pt]
  \ln y &= \pm 6\ln x \\[16pt]
  \ln y &= \ln (1/x^6)\hspace{0.25em}\text{ or }\hspace{0.25em}\ln (x^6) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.2em} \answer{y = \dfrac{1}{x^6}\hspace{0.25em}\text{ or }\hspace{0.25em}x^6}
  $$

list.title: Question 39
list.content: Consider the graphs of $y = -\dfrac{1}{2}|x|$ and $y = 2|x| - a$, where $a \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. - Sketch the graphs on the same set of axes. [2] - Given that the graphs enclose a region of area 40 square units, find the value of $a$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- If we sketch the graphs of $y = -\dfrac{1}{2}|x|$ and
$y = 2|x| - a$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1f7ba47-5c7f-4483-baa8-4c9fa89f8efb/images/52d9876b-801d-4d99-bd5b-65f532bdeb39/68ec0f82b42dd94d75c48aa4929409d0a553c4d8.svg)


- The two lines in the $4$th quadrant intersect when

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.4em} -\dfrac{1}{2}x &= 2x -a \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x > 0$}] \\[6pt]
  -x &= 4x - 2a \\[10pt]
  2a &= 5x \\[6pt]
  x &= \dfrac{2a}{5}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the area enclosed between
the two graphs is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2}(\text{base}\times\text{height})\bigg] &= 2\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2}\Big(a\times\dfrac{2a}{5}\Big)\bigg] \hspace{2.2em} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{2a^2}{5}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, given that the area is $40$
square units, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{2a^2}{5} &= 40 \\[6pt]
  a^2 &= 100 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.7em} \answer{a = 10}
  $$

list.title: Question 42
list.content: Let $f(x) = ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{Q}$. The diagram below shows part of the graph of $y = f(x)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d78a10f2-621e-426c-91f2-9dea87dbacc5/images/89842500-91d4-4b78-a494-6ce2510b4acf/f2e9d58912ae2f10d7fdf9d12ee3b7594c2c45fb.svg) - Using the information shown in the diagram, find the values of $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$.[4] - Let $g(x) = -\dfrac{3}{4}f(-2x+1)$. - Find the coordinates of the points where the graph of $y = g(x)$ intercepts the $x$-axis. - Find the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- From the diagram, we see that the roots of the polynomial equation
$f(x) = 0$ are $-3$, $-1$ and $3$.
  Hence, using the factor theorem, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= a(x-3)(x+1)(x+3) \\[6pt]
  &= a(x^2-9)(x+1) \\[6pt]
  &= a(x^3 + x^2 - 9x - 9) \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we substitute
$x = 0$ in the expression $(1)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} f(0) &= a(0^3 + 0^2 - 9(0) - 9) \\[12pt]
  -3 &= -9a \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(0) = -3$}] \\[6pt]
  a &= \dfrac{1}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we substitute $a = 1/3$ in the
expression $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= \dfrac{1}{3}(x^3 + x^2 - 9x - 9) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{3}x^3 + \dfrac{1}{3}x^2 - 3x - 3 \hspace{1.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = b = \dfrac{1}{3}}$
and  $\answer{c = d = -3}$
- 
  - Solving the equation $g(x) = 0$ for $x$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    -\dfrac{3}{4}f(-2x + 1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
    f(-2x + 1) &= 0 \\[12pt]
    -2x + 1 &= -3,\hspace{0.25em} -1,\hspace{0.25em} 3 \hspace{4em} \\[12pt]
    -2x &= -4,\hspace{0.25em} -2,\hspace{0.25em} 2 \\[12pt]
    x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em}1,\hspace{0.25em}2\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
the coordinates of the $x$-intercepts of the graph of $y = g(x)$
are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \answer{(-1,0),\hspace{0.25em}(1,0),\hspace{0.25em}(2,0)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $y=g(x)$ for $x = 0$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10.9em} y &= g(0) \\[10pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}f(2(0)+1) \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}f(1) \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}\hspace{-0.2em}\left[\dfrac{1}{3}(1)^3 + \dfrac{1}{3}(1)^2 - 3(1) - 3\right] \\[4pt]
    &=-\dfrac{3}{4}\hspace{-0.2em}\left[-\dfrac{16}{3}\right] \\[10pt]
    &= 4\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $y$-intercept of the graph of
$y = g(x)$ is
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,4)}$

list.title: Question 43
list.content: Consider $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{2} - \ln\left(\sqrt{x^2-4}\right)$. - Find the largest possible domain $D$ for $f$ to be a function. [2] The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{2} - \ln\left(\sqrt{x^2-4}\right)$, for $x \in D$. - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, showing clearly the equations of asymptotes and the coordinates of any intercepts with the axes. [3] - Explain why $f$ is an even function. [1] - Explain why the inverse function $f^{-1}$ does not exist. [1] The function $g$ is defined by $g(x) = \dfrac{1}{2} - \ln\left(\sqrt{x^2-4}\right)$, for $x \in (2,\infty)$. - Find the inverse function $g^{-1}$ and state its domain. [4]
list.markScheme:
- The square root function is defined on $[0,\infty)$ and natural
logarithm function is defined on $(0,\infty)$.
  Hence $f$ is a function if

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \textstyle \sqrt{x^2-4} &> 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  x^2-4 &> 0 \\[6pt]
  x^2 &> 4 \\[6pt]
  |x| &> 2 \\[6pt]
  x < -2 \hspace{0.5em}&\hspace{0.2em}\text{or}\hspace{0.7em} x > 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the largest possible domain for $f$ to be a function is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{D = (-\infty,-2)\cup(2,\infty)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/18ea91ad-1794-4924-860f-5cce1a2aaaa5/images/52aadecb-f956-431e-9b31-87bfc4bc127b/c292af76cbb30669709b70ec8dbfa255472cb0f7.svg)


- $\answer{\text{The function \(f\) is even because its graph is symmetric about the \(y\)-axis.}}$
  OR
  $\answer{\text{The function \(f\) is even because it satisfies \(f(x) = f(-x)\) for all \(x \in D\).}}$
- $\answer{\text{The inverse function \(f^{-1}\) does not exist because \(f\) is not bijective.}}$
- If we solve the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[15pt]
  g(y) &= x \\[10pt]
  \dfrac{1}{2} - \textstyle \ln\hspace{-0.1em}\big(\sqrt{y^2-4}\big) &= x \\[6pt]
  \textstyle \ln\hspace{-0.1em}\big(\sqrt{y^2-4}\big) &= \dfrac{1}{2} - x  \\[9pt]
  \textstyle \sqrt{y^2-4} &= e^{\left(\frac{1}{2} - x\right)} \\[12pt]
  y^2-4 &= e^{2\left(\frac{1}{2} - x\right)} \\[14pt]
  y^2 &= e^{1 - 2x} + 4 \\[13pt]
  y &= \textstyle \sqrt{e^{1 - 2x} + 4} \hspace{2.7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence an expression for $g^{-1}$ is
$\answer{g^{-1}(x) = \sqrt{e^{1 - 2x} + 4}}$
  The domain of $g^{-1}$ is
$\answer{\mathbb{R}}$

list.title: Question 44
list.content: Let $f(x) = x^4 - x^3 - 5x^2 + 3x + 2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Solve the inequality $f(x) < 0$. [3] - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the coordinates of the local maximum point. Round your answers to three significant figures. [3] The domain of $f$ is now restricted to $[a,b]$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$. - - Write down the smallest value of $a < 0$ and the largest value of $b > 0$ for which $f$ has an inverse. Give your answers correct to three significant figures. - For these values of $a$ and $b$, sketch the graphs of $y = f(x)$ and $y = f^{-1}(x)$ on the same set of axes, showing clearly the coordinates of the end points of each curve. - Solve the equation $f^{-1}(x) = -1$. [6]
list.markScheme:
- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4511e74b-84ed-4f18-954c-18a8e7a56dc2/images/24541222-4ef2-4f83-8869-c493d5ca3b7d/9444e78d503e38688d4c8ecfe5c29f2d0705556f.svg)


  From the diagram, we see that $f$ is positive on the intervals
$(-\infty,-2)$, $(-0.414,1)$ and $(2.41,\infty)$, and negative on
$(-2,-0.414)$ and $(1,2.41)$.
  Hence the set of solutions to the inequality $f(x) < 0$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{(-2,-0.414)\cup(1,2.41)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- From the diagram, we see that the graph of $y = f(x)$ has a local
maximum at point B.
  Hence the coordinates of the local maximum point are
$\answer{(0.285, 2.43)}$
- 
  - From the diagram, we see that $f$ is a bijection if its domain
is restricted to $[-1.14,0.285]$ or $[0.285,1.87]$.
Hence $f$ has an inverse if
$\answer{a = -1.41}$
and  $\answer{b = 0.285}$
  - The graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ is a reflection of the graph of
$y = f(x)$ across the line $y = x$.
    Hence, if we sketch the graphs of $y = f(x)$ and $y = f^{-1}(x)$
on the same set of axes, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4511e74b-84ed-4f18-954c-18a8e7a56dc2/images/81733c2d-4f9c-47f5-bd1c-45eb231fe561/b6185b0f42f1522008f7c0707456fd536c854029.svg)


  - If we solve the equation $f^{-1}(x) = -1$ for $x$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(f^{-1}(x)) &= f(-1) \hspace{4em} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{10.7em} \answer{x = -4} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(f^{-1}(x)) = x$}]
    $$

list.title: Question 45
list.content: The graph of $y=f(x)$ for $0\leq x \leq 6$ is shown below ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/d9b698f4-a101-40b3-a118-dbc3aa80bdc7/AA1279-q1.JPEG) The odd function $h(x)$ has the domain $-6\leq x \leq 6$ and $h(x)=2f(x)$ for $0\leq x \leq 6$. - Sketch $h(x)$ on the axes above.[2] $f(x)$ is shown again below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/3a60566c-11b7-4cc2-ac58-301a1f0b734a/AA1279-q2.JPEG) - Sketch the graph of $y=[f(x)]^2$ on the axes above.[3] $f(x)$ is shown one more time below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/6712f3c3-7980-49b2-be9d-09510dd7213d/AA1279-q3.JPEG) - Sketch the graph of $y=\dfrac{1}{f(x)}$ on the axes above.[3]
list.markScheme:
- Let's start with graphing $y=2f(x)$.
  This is a vertical stretch by a scale factor of 2.
  The distance of all $y-$coordinates from the $x-$axis are multiplied by two.
  The key point $(2, 2)$ will become $(2, 4)$.  This is shown in the graph below in $\textcolor{red}{\text{red}}$.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/ee8f2b59-189d-4582-b80f-8543d1539c11/AA1279-a1.JPEG)


  The definition of an odd function is $f(-x)=-f(x)$. This transformation represents rotational symmetry of order $2$ about the origin which is equivalent to performing two reflections, one in each axis, in any order.
  Therefore, to complete the rest of the graph of $h(x)$, we can either take the graph of $y=2f(x)$ and rotate it $180^\circ$ about the origin or perform two reflections, one in each axis. Both result in the same final position.
  If we consider the reflection approach. First, we perform $f(x) \rightarrow f(-x)$, this is a reflection in the $y-$axis. This is the dotted blue line shown in the following graph.
  Then we consider $f(-x)\rightarrow-f(-x)$, this is a reflection in the $x-$axis.
  This fully transformed part is shown in solid $\textcolor{blue}{\text{blue}}$ in the following graph.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/e98b48c5-6b88-483c-9505-e090a80ebdda/AA1279-a2.JPEG)


  The final graph of $y=h(x)$ is shown below
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/36471d45-1f48-4d32-ac28-33498e303129/AA1279-a3.JPEG)



  $$
  \begin{align*}
      \answer{\text{Correct points at }(-2, -4)\text{ and }(-6,0)}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
       \answer{\text{Correct transformation(s)}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- First, let's look at the section of the graph $0\leq x \leq 2$.
  We can use the properties of the transformation $[f(x)]^2$ to identify some key points.
  We know that if $f(x)=0$ then $[f(x)]^2=0$.
  We also know that if $f(x)=1$ then $[f(x)]^2=1$.
  It is important to also realise that if $-1<f(x)<1$ then $[f(x)]^2<f(x)$.
  Therefore between $0<x<1$ then $[f(x)]^2<f(x)$.
  Using the end point of the first part of the curve we can see that $[f(2)]^2=4$.
  Using the key points $(0,0)$, $(1,1)$ and $(2,4)$ we can sketch the transformed curve, shown in $\textcolor{red}{\text{red}}$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/1850a5f9-cc57-42c9-aced-4f5076f93f70/AA1279-a4.JPEG)


  Now, let's look at the section of the graph $2\leq x \leq 6$.
  We know the second section will start at $(2,4)$ and finish at $(6,0)$.
  Using the property if $f(x)=1$ then $[f(x)]^2=1$ we know the curve will intersect the original function at $f(x)=1$.
  Which we can see is at $(4,1)$.
  It is important to clearly show on the graph that $[f(x)]^2<f(x)$ when $0<f(x)<1$.
  With this in mind, using the key points $(2,4)$, $(1,4)$ and $(6,0)$ we can sketch the second part, shown in $\textcolor{blue}{\text{blue}}$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/df6ea7d7-12e8-4c02-9e9e-59b469c720e1/AA1279-a5.JPEG)


  The final graph of $y=[f(x)]^2$ is shown below
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/d8f9fbfb-5406-4219-9359-a6a3e373e1ae/AA1279-a6.JPEG)



  $$
  \begin{align*}
      &\answer{\text{Correct shape}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
      &\answer{\text{$f(x)=[f(x)]^2$ when $f(x)=0,1$}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
      &\answer{\text{$[f(x)]^2$} \text{ is less than } f(x) \text{ when } 0<f(x)<1}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Let's start by drawing the vertical asymptotes.
  They will occur at the $x$-intercepts of $f(x)$ which are $x=0$ and $x=6$. Shown below as the dotted red vertical lines
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/e1ad22e1-6249-4f31-ba13-092dd647afbb/AA1279-a7.JPEG)


  Let's consider the key point $(2,2)$, after the transformation this point will become $(2,\tfrac{1}{2})$.
  Considering the asymptotes, we can see that as $x\rightarrow 0$ and $x\rightarrow 6$ then $f(x)\rightarrow 0$ (from the positive direction) therefore $\frac{1}{f(x)}\rightarrow \infty^+$.

  &\answer{\text{Correct shape}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]

  $$

list.title: Question 46
list.content: It is given that $f(x) = 2x^4 + 5x^3 + ax^2 + bx + 4$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$. - Given that $x^2 + x - 2$ is a factor of $f(x)$, find the values of $a$ and $b$. [4] - Factorise $f(x)$ into a product of linear factors. [4] - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, labeling the maximum and minimum points and the $x$ and $y$ intercepts. [3] - Using your graph, state the range of values of $c$ for which $f(x) = c$ has exactly four real roots. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Factorising $x^2 + x - 2$ into a product of linear factors, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^2 + x - 2 = (x-1)(x+2)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $(x-1)$ and $(x+2)$
are both factors of $f(x)$.
  Hence, using the factor theorem, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  2(1)^4 + 5(1)^3 + a(1)^2 + b(1) + 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  2 + 5 + a + b + 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  a + b &= -11 \hspace{3em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the factor theorem again, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-2) &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
  2(-2)^4 + 5(-2)^3 + a(-2)^2 + b(-2) + 4 &= 0 \\[7pt]
  32 - 40 + 4a - 2b + 4 &= 0 \\[7pt]
  4a - 2b &= 4 \\[7pt]
  2a - b &= 2 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the system of
two linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{a = -3}\hspace{0.525em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{b = -8}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we divide $2x^4 + 5x^3 - 3x^2 - 8x + 4$ by $x^2 + x - 2$, we have
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= 2x^4 + 5x^3 - 3x^2 - 8x + 4 \\[6pt]
  &= (x^2 + x - 2)(2x^2 + 3x - 2) \\[6pt]
  &= (x-1)(x+2)(2x-1)(x+2) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= (x-1)(2x-1)(x+2)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1bd4cd72-a9fa-45a6-960b-36cd2036ef37/images/aab0e32b-f24b-45b1-918c-1af7fb3e580b/fee6121260f114c0cc689969551419dd8b20d6fc.svg)


- From the diagram, we see that the equation $f(x) = c$ has exactly
four real
  roots when
$\answer{0 < c < 6.92}$

list.title: Question 47
list.content: - Sketch the curve $y = -\left|\dfrac{5}{x-2}\right|$ and line $y = -x - 4$ on the same axes, clearly indicating any $x$ and $y$ intercepts and any asymptotes. [3] - Find the exact solutions to the equation $x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- Let $f(x) = -\left|\dfrac{5}{x-2}\right|$ where $x \in \mathbb{R}$,
$x \neq 2$.
  Since $f(x) < 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \neq 2$, the curve
$y = f(x)$ has no $x$-intercepts.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} y &= f(0) \\[12pt]
  &= -\left|-\dfrac{5}{2}\right| \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{5}{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point A$(0,-5/2)$ is the
$y$-intercept of the curve $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \lim_{x \rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) = 0 \hspace{3.9em}
  $$

  Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal asymptote of the curve
$y = f(x)$.
  The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x = 2$. Hence the line $x = 2$
is a vertical asymptote of the curve $y = f(x)$.
  The $x$ and $y$ intercepts of the line $y = -4-x$ are B$(-4,0)$ and
C$(0,-4)$.
  If we sketch the curve $y = f(x)$ and line $y = -x - 4$ on the same
axes, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3ce10e6d-6009-49da-a002-42ae1d773968/images/2248acaa-10a6-4043-b8a6-84823cf01ad6/38ce371d4e9621963b29074adf6413c8b9f71c7c.svg)


- If we solve the equation $x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$ for $x < 2$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x + 4 &= -\dfrac{5}{x-2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x - 2 < 0$}] \\[9pt]
  \hspace{7.7em} (x+4)(x-2) &= -5 \\[12pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 8 &= -5 \\[12pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 3 &= 0 \\[13pt]
  (x + 3)(x - 1) &= 0 \\[13pt]
  x &= -3,\hspace{0.25em} 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we simplify the equation
$x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$ for $x > 2$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x + 4 &= \dfrac{5}{x-2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x - 2 > 0$}] \\[9pt]
  \hspace{10em} (x+4)(x-2) &= 5 \\[13pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 8 &= 5 \\[13pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 13 &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the quadratic
formula, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{12em} x &= \dfrac{-2+\sqrt{2^2-4(1)(-13)}}{2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x > 2$}] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{-2+2\sqrt{14}}{2} \\[12pt]
  &= -1 + \sqrt{14} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
exact solutions to the equation $\text{\(x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}\)}$ are  $\answer{-3,\hspace{0.25em}1,\hspace{0.25em}\textstyle -1 + \sqrt{14}}$

list.title: Question 48
list.content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = 1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3}$, for $x \neq -3$. - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, indicating clearly any asymptotes and points of intersection with the $x$ and $y$ axes. [4] - Find an expression for $f^{-1}$. [4] - Find all values of $x$ for which $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$. [3] - Solve the inequality $|f(x)| < 2$. [4] - Solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= 0 \\[11pt]
  5x + 3 &= 0 \\[10pt]
  x &= -\dfrac{3}{5} \hspace{2.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
P$(-3/5,0)$ is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
  &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point Q$(0,1)$ is the $y$-intercept of
the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) &= 1 + \dfrac{4}{1} \hspace{3.7em} \\[6pt]
  &= 5\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the line $y = 5$ is a horizontal asymptote
of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x = -3$. Hence the line
$x = -3$
is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  If we sketch of the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b02f9456-fc87-4d72-8046-b8ad6f17fd88/images/80e5d1bc-25e1-48da-ad0b-cf11c4df076c/a4ee5024679811f4302b4cf52d17f68170c60827.svg)


- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \hspace{3.7em}  \\[8pt]
  f\left(y\right) &= x\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} 1+ \dfrac{4y}{y+3} &= x \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5y+3}{y+3} &= x \\[10pt]
  5y+3 &= xy+3x \\[16pt]
  (5-x)y &= 3x-3 \\[10pt]
  y &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence an expression for
$f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x}}$
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= f^{-1}(x) \\[9pt]
  1 + \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[10pt]
  (5x+3)(5-x) &= (3x-3)(x+3) \\[12pt]
  \hspace{1.6em} 25x - 5x^2 + 15 -3x &= 3x^2 + 9x -3x - 9 \\[12pt]
  -8x^2 + 16x + 24 &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^2 - 2x - 3 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  (x+1)(x-3) &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.6em} \answer{x = -1,\hspace{0.25em}3}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{8.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  && |f(x)| &<& 2 \\[13pt]
  -2 &<& f(x) &<& 2 \\[12pt]
  f^{-1}(-2) &<& x &<& f^{-1}(2) \hspace{2em} [\text{since $f^{-1}(f(x)) = x$}]
  \end{array}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x = -2$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.4em} f^{-1}(-2) &= \dfrac{3(-2)-3}{5-(-2)} \\[3pt]
  &= -\dfrac{9}{7} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for
$x = 2$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} f^{-1}(2) &= \dfrac{3(2)-3}{5-2}  \hspace{0.8em} \\[8pt]
  &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the inequality
$|f(x)| < 2$ is
$\answer{-\frac{9}{7}<x<1}$
- If we solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ for $|x|$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} 1+ \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 2 \\[5pt]
  \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 1 \\[10pt]
  4|x| &< |x|+3 \\[16pt]
  3|x| &< 3 \\[16pt]
  |x| &< 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ is
$\answer{-1<x<1}$

list.content: Consider the function $f(x)=5xe^x+1$. The function has a single point of inflexion at $A$. - Show that the point of inflexion of $f(x)$ occurs when $x=-2$. [3] - Sketch $f(x)$ on the grid below, label point $A$ and any asymptotes.[1] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04090a8e-6d70-4a75-a5e4-341287b09a7d/images/0957c93a-b030-4309-ad29-4635f77a12cf/AA1156_q.JPEG) - The line $g(x)=mx+c$ passes through $A$ for all values of $m$ and $c$. - Evaluate $m$ when $g(x)$ is tangent to $f(x)$ at point $A$. - Hence find the range of values of $m$ for which $f(x)=g(x)$ has exactly $3$ solutions.
