list.title: Question 51
list.content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = e^{2x}-4e^x+2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \leq a$, where $a \in \mathbb{R}$. Part of the graph of $y = f(x)$ is shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4c5c56b3-ccff-4218-8eeb-ed43662a5361/images/6b8a627c-1929-4344-ac27-a9f1d77bd6ab/dc14321f698d30780f4ecaf20c082a22181a9565.svg) - Find the largest value of $a$ such that $f$ has an inverse function. [3] - For this value of $a$, find an expression for $f^{-1}(x)$, stating its domain. [5]
list.markScheme:
- From the diagram, we see that the $x$-coordinate of the local
minimum point on the graph of $y = f(x)$ is the largest value of $a$
such that $f$ has an inverse function.
  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[e^{2x}-4e^x+2\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 2e^{2x}-4e^x \\[9pt]
  &= \big[2e^x\big]\big[e^x - 2\big]\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we solve the equation $f'(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \big[2e^x\big]\big[e^x - 2\big] &= 0 \hspace{5.2em} \\[6pt]
  e^x - 2 &= 0 \\[7pt]
  e^x &= 2 \\[7pt]
  x &= \ln 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = \ln 2}$
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y =  f^{-1}(x)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \hspace{3em} [\text{where $-2 \leq x < 2$}] \\[9pt]
  f(y) &= x \hspace{3em} [\text{where $y \leq \ln 2$}] \\[7pt]
  e^{2y}-4e^y+2 &= x \\[7pt]
  \big[(e^y)^2-4e^y\big]+2 &= x \\[7pt]
  \hspace{7.1em} \big[(e^y-2)^2 - 4\big]+2 &= x \hspace{3em} [\text{by completing the square}] \\[7pt]
  (e^y-2)^2 &= x+2 \\[7pt]
  e^y-2 &= \pm\sqrt{x+2} \\[7pt]
  e^y-2 &= -\sqrt{x+2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $y \leq \ln 2$}] \\[7pt]
  e^y &= 2-\sqrt{x+2} \\[7pt]
  y &= \ln (2-\sqrt{x+2})\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \ln (2-\sqrt{x+2}), \text{ for } x \in \mathbb{R}, -2 \leq x < 2}$

list.title: Question 52
list.content: This question asks you to investigate some properties of even and odd functions. Consider the functions $f_1(x)=\dfrac{5}{x^3}$ and $f_2(x)=3x^2+8$. - Determine whether: - The function $f_1(x)$ is an even function or an odd function, - The function $f_2(x)$ is an even function or an odd function.[4] Suppose $g(x)$ is a function with domain $\mathbb{R}$ and let $h$ and $j$ be the functions $$ \begin{align*} h(x)=\dfrac{g(x)+g(-x)}{2},\quad j(x)=\dfrac{g(x)-g(-x)}{2}\\[-12pt] \end{align*} $$ - - Show that $g(x)=h(x)+j(x).$ - Hence, show that $g(x)$ is the sum of an even and an odd function.[4] - Using the results from part (b), find the even part and the odd part of $g(x)=x^4+4x^3+5x^2-2x$[3] Let $f(x)$ be a function that is differentiable for all $x \in \mathbb{R}.$ - Show that: - if $f(x)$ is an even function, then $f'(x)$ is an odd function - if $f(x)$ is an odd function, then $f'(x)$ is an even function.[4] - Show that if $f(x)$ is an even function defined and differentiable at $x=0,$ then: - $f'(0)=0$, - $f^{2k+1}(0)=0$ for $k \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, - its Maclaurin series expansion contains only even powers of $x$.[5] - Show that if $f(x)$ is an odd function, then its Maclaurin series expansion contains only odd powers of $x.$ [5]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Evaluating $f_1$ at $-x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f_1(-x) & =\dfrac{5}{(-x)^3} \\[8pt]
    &=-\dfrac{5}{x^3}\\[8pt]
    &= -f_1(x) \\[-10pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Since $f_1(-x)=-f_1(x)$, $\answer{\text{the function $f_1(x)$ is an odd function.}}$
  - Evaluating $f_2$ at $-x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f_2(-x) &=3(-x)^2+8 \\[8pt]
    &=3x^2+8\\[8pt]
    &= f_2(x) \\[-10pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Since $f_2(-x)=f_2(x),$ $\answer{\text{ the function $f_2(x)$ is an even function.}}$

- 
  - Taking the sum of $h$ and $j$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    h(x)+j(x)&=\dfrac{g(x)+g(-x)}{2}+\dfrac{g(x)-g(-x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &=\dfrac{2g(x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-5.2em}\tcbhighmath{h(x)+j(x) = g(x)}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Evaluating $h$ at $-x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    h(-x)&=\dfrac{g(-x)+g(x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &= \dfrac{g(x)+g(-x)}{2} \\[12pt]
    &=h(x)\\[-11pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, $h(x)$ is an even function.
    Now, evaluating $j$ at $-x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    j(-x)&=\dfrac{g(-x)-g(x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &=-\dfrac{g(x)-g(-x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &=-j(x)\\[-11pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, $j(x)$ is an odd function.
    Since $g(x)=h(x)+j(x)$, any function $g(x)$ can be written as the sum of an even function and an odd function.

- Evaluating $g$ at $-x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  g(-x)&=(-x)^4+4(-x)^3+5(-x)^2-2(-x)\\[12pt]
  &=x^4-4x^3+5x^2+2x
  \end{align*}
  $$

  From part (b), the even part of $g(x)$ is $h(x)$.

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h(x)&=\dfrac{g(x)+g(-x)}{2} \\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{(x^4+4x^3+5x^2-2x)+(x^4-4x^3+5x^2+2x)}{2}\\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{2x^4+10x^2}{2}\\[12pt]
  &\hspace{0.275em}\tcbhighmath{= x^4+5x^2}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The odd part of $g(x)$ is $j(x)$.

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  j(x)&=\dfrac{g(x)-g(-x)}{2}\\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{(x^4+4x^3+5x^2-2x)-(x^4-4x^3+5x^2+2x)}{2}\\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{8x^3-4x}{2}\\[12pt]    
  &\hspace{0.275em}\tcbhighmath{=4x^3-2x }
  \end{align*}
  $$

- 
  - Let's suppose that $f(x)$ is an even function. Thus, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f(-x) &= f(x) \\[12pt]
    -f'(-x) &= f'(x)\\[12pt]
    f'(-x) &= -f'(x)\\[-9pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore,$\,\,\answer{\text{ $f'(x)$ is an odd function.}}$
  - Let's suppose that $f(x)$ is an odd function. Thus, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f(-x) &= -f(x) \\[12pt]
    -f'(-x)&=-f'(x)\\[12pt]
    f'(-x) &= f'(x)\\[-9pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, $\,\answer{\text{ $f'(x)$ is an even function.}}$

- 
  - By part (d), if $f(x)$ is an even function then $f'(x)$ is an odd function. We get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f'(-0)&=-f'(0)\\[12pt]
    f'(0) &=-f'(0)\\[12pt]
    2f'(0) &= 0 \\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-2.4em}\tcbhighmath{f'(0) = 0}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Using part (d) (i), $f(x)$ even $\Rightarrow f'(x)$ odd.
    Using part (d) (ii), $f'(x)$ odd $\Rightarrow f''(x)$ even.
    By iteration, we have that every odd derivative is an odd function and every even derivative is an even function. That is, $f^{2k+1}(x)$ is odd and $f^{2k}(x)$ is even for $k \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. Hence,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f^{2k+1}(-x)&=-f^{2k+1}(x)\\[12pt]
    f^{2k+1}(-0)&=-f^{2k+1}(0)\\[12pt]
    f^{2k+1}(0) &=-f^{2k+1}(0)\\[12pt]
    2f^{2k+1}(0) &= 0 \\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-3.85em}\tcbhighmath{f^{2k+1}(0) = 0}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - The Maclaurin series expansion of $f(x)$ is

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f(x)=f(0)+xf'(0)+\dfrac{x^2}{2!}f''(0)+\dfrac{x^3}{3!}f^{(3)}(0)+\cdots
    \end{align*}
    $$

    From part (ii), $f'(0)=0$ and $f^{2k+1}(0)=0$ for $k \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, which means that
    The only non-zero terms remaining in the Maclaurin series expansion are those of the form $\dfrac{x^{2k}}{(2k)!}f^{2k}(0)$, those with even powers of $x$, including the constant term.

- By part (d), if $f(x)$ is an odd function then $f'(x)$ is an even function and $f''(x)$ is an odd function. Using parts (d) (i) and (ii), by iteration, every even derivative is an odd function.
  We can say that $f^{2k}(x)$ is an odd function for $k \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. Thus, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  f^{2k}(-x) &= -f^{2k}(x) \\[12pt]
  f^{2k}(-0)&=-f^{2k}(0)\\[12pt]
  f^{2k}(0)&=-f^{2k}(0)\\[12pt]
  2f^{2k}(0) &= 0 \\[12pt]
  f^{2k}(0) &= 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The Maclaurin series expansion of $f(x)$ is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  f(x)=f(0)+xf'(0)+\dfrac{x^2}{2!}f''(0)+\dfrac{x^3}{3!}f^{(3)}(0)+\cdots
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore the terms with even powers in the Maclaurin series of $f(x)$ vanish and the Maclaurin series of $f(x)$ contains only terms with odd powers of $x$.

list.title: Question 53
list.content: Let $f(x) = x^4 - 0.4\hspace{0.05em}x^3 - 2.85\hspace{0.05em}x^2 + 0.9\hspace{0.05em}x + 1.35$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find the solutions for $f(x) > 0$. [3] - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, - find the coordinates of local minimum and maximum points. - find the $x$-coordinates of the points of inflexion. [5] The domain of $f$ is now restricted to $[a,b]$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - - Write down the smallest value of $a > 0$ and the largest value of $b > 0$ for which $f$ has an inverse. Give your answers correct to three significant figures. - For these values of $a$ and $b$, sketch the graphs of $y = f(x)$ and $y = f^{-1}(x)$ on the same set of axes, showing clearly the coordinates of the end points of each curve. - Solve $f^{-1}(x) = 0.5$. [6] Let $g(x) = \dfrac{2}{3}\sin(2x - 1) + \dfrac{1}{2}$, $\dfrac{1}{2} - \dfrac{\pi}{4} \leq x \leq \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{\pi}{4}$. - - Find an expression for $g^{-1}$ and state its domain. - Solve $(f^{-1}\circ g)(x) < 0.5$. [8]
list.markScheme:
- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b276ac45-671f-4c75-9dea-a3774fc53f67/images/44e18fcd-818c-481b-aabd-bbc35f210168/245a2a1979fce06233cc54e60878b1e96f11b9d1.svg)


  From the diagram, we see that $f$ is positive on the intervals
$(-\infty,-1.5)$, $(-0.6,1)$ and $(1.5,\infty)$, and negative on
$(-1.5,-0.6)$ and $(1,1.5)$.
  Hence the set of solutions to the inequality $f(x) > 0$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{(-\infty,-1.5)\cup(-0.6,1)\cup(1.5,\infty)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - From the diagram, we see that the graph of $y = f(x)$ has a
local
maximum at point A and local minimums at points B and C.
    Hence the coordinates of the local max and min points are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \text{local max}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(0.155, 1.42)} \vspace{0.75em} \\[10pt]
    \text{local min}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(-1.13, -1.10)}\hspace{0.525em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(1.28, -0.322)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(x) &= x^4 - 0.4x^3 - 2.85x^2 + 0.9x + 1.35 \\[6pt]
    f'(x) &= 4x^3 - 1.2x^2 - 5.7x + 0.9 \\[6pt]
    \hspace{1.5em} f''(x) &= 12x^2 - 2.4x - 5.7\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, if we solve the equation
$f''(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    12x^2 - 2.4x - 5.7 &= 0 \hspace{9.8em} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{12.95em} \answer{x \approx -0.596, \hspace{0.25em} 0.796} \hspace{2.5em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
    $$


- 
  - From the diagram, we see that $f$ is a bijection if its domain
is restricted to $[-1.13, 0.155]$ or $[0.155,1.28]$.
    As it is given that $a,b > 0$, hence $f$ has an inverse if
$\answer{a = 0.155}$
and  $\answer{b = 1.28}$
  - The graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ is the reflection of the graph of
$y = f(x)$ across the line $y = x$.
    Hence, if we sketch the graphs of $y = f(x)$ and $y = f^{-1}(x)$
on the same set of axes, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b276ac45-671f-4c75-9dea-a3774fc53f67/images/3ebbda78-45c5-40ce-9d82-70daf75779a2/524a320d1d2563d4a110444319e1f709eb5ee6c6.svg)


  - If we solve the equation $f^{-1}(x) = 0.5$ for $x$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(f^{-1}(x)) &= f(0.5) \hspace{4em} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{10.8em} \answer{x = 1.1} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(f^{-1}(x)) = x$}]
    $$


- 
  - Solving the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[14pt]
    g(y) &= x \\[10pt]
    \hspace{1.7em} \dfrac{2}{3}\sin(2y - 1) + \dfrac{1}{2} &= x \\[6pt]
    \dfrac{2}{3}\sin(2y - 1) &= \dfrac{2x-1}{2} \\[6pt]
    \sin(2y - 1) &= \dfrac{6x-3}{4} \\[4pt]
    2y - 1 &= \arcsin\bigg(\hspace{-0.05em}\dfrac{6x-3}{4}\bigg) \\[3pt]
    y &= \dfrac{1}{2}\arcsin\bigg(\hspace{-0.05em}\dfrac{6x-3}{4}\bigg) + \dfrac{1}{2} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence an expression for $g^{-1}$ is
$\answer{g^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{1}{2}\arcsin\bigg(\hspace{-0.05em}\dfrac{6x-3}{4}\bigg) + \dfrac{1}{2}}$
The range of $g$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \left[-\dfrac{2}{3}+\dfrac{1}{2},\hspace{0.25em}\dfrac{2}{3}+\dfrac{1}{2}\right] = \left[-\dfrac{1}{6},\hspace{0.25em}\dfrac{7}{6}\right] \hspace{4.7em}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the domain of $g^{-1}$ is
$\answer{\bigg[-\dfrac{1}{6},\dfrac{7}{6}\bigg]}$
  - Solving the inequality $(f^{-1}\circ g)(x) < 0.5$ for $x$, we
get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{9.5em} f^{-1}(g(x)) &< 0.5 \\[6pt]
    g(x) &> f(0.5) \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f$ is decreasing}] \\[6pt]
    g(x) &> 1.1 \\[5pt]
    x &> g^{-1}(1.1) \hspace{2em} [\text{since $g^{-1}$ is increasing}] \\[6pt]
    x &> 1.06\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $(f^{-1}\circ g)(x) < 0.5$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \answer{\left(1.06,\hspace{0.25em}\dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{\pi}{4}\right]} \hspace{2em}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 54
list.content: Consider the function $g(x)=ax^3+bx^2+cx+d$, where $x\in \mathbb{R}$ and $a$, $b$, $c$, $d \in \mathbb{R}.$ - - Write down an expression for $g'(x)$. - Hence, given that $g^{-1}$ does not exist, show that $b^2-3ac>0.$[3] Consider the function $f(x)=\dfrac{x^3}{2}+3x^2+6x+\dfrac{9}{2}$ - - Show that $f^{-1}$ exists. - $f(x)$ can be written in the form $p\hspace{0.05em}(x+2)^3+q$, where $p$, $q\in \mathbb{R}$. Find the value of $p$ and the value of $q$. - Hence, find $f^{-1}(x)$.[7] The graph of $f(x)$ may be obtained by transforming the graph of $y=x^3$ using a sequence of three transformations. - State each of the transformations in the order in which they are applied.[3] - Sketch the graphs of $y=f(x)$ and $y=f^{-1}(x)$ on the same set of axes, indicating the points where each graph crosses the coordinate axes.[4]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Taking the derivative with respect to $x$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    g'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\hspace{0.1em} \big[ ax^3+bx^2+cx+d \big] \\[12pt]
    &\answer{= 3ax^2+2bx+c} \end{aligned}
    $$

  - As $g^{-1}$ does not exist, the graph of $g$ should have two
turning points. Thus, the derivative has a strictly positive
discriminant, this is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \big[\text{discriminant of $g'$}\big] &> 0 \\[12pt]
    (2b)^2 - 4(3a)(c) &> 0 \hspace{3.5em} [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac] \\[12pt]
    4b^2 - 12ac &> 0 \\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-1.25cm}\answer{b^2-3ac > 0} \end{aligned}
    $$


- 
  - Using part (a) (ii), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    (3)^2-3\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\left(6\right) & \ngtr 0. \end{aligned}
    $$

    Therefore, by the contrapositive statement to part (a) (ii), we
deduce $f^{-1}$ exists.
  - Factorizing the expression for $y=f(x)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(x) &= \dfrac{1}{2}\left(x^3+6x^2+12x+9\right) \\[10pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2}\left(x^3+6x^2+12x+8+1\right)  \\[10pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2}\left(x+2\right)^3 + \dfrac{1}{2}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Therefore
$\answer{p=\dfrac{1}{2}, \, q=\dfrac{1}{2}}$
  - If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
    f(y) &= x \\[10pt]
    \dfrac{1}{2}(y+2)^3+\dfrac{1}{2} &= x \\[10pt]
    (y+2)^3 &= 2x - 1 \\[12pt]
    y+2 &= \sqrt[3]{2x-1} \\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-10.5mm}\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]{2x-1} - 2} \end{aligned}
    $$


- We get the following transformations

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{transformation $1$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{horizontal translation $2$ units left}} \\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $2$}&:
  \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical stretch by a factor of $\dfrac{1}{2}$}}\\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $3$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical translation $\dfrac{1}{2}$ units up}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Note: The horizontal translation can be performed in any step but
the
vertical stretch should be performed before the vertical
translation.
- Using the shape of a cubic function, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bad00ea0-0b26-414f-a642-5211980e8eb3/images/6f61d4f5-598d-4c89-a21d-4c9ec4d63076/79b23cf27cdbbbaba59cb5e2eee4c41cd47b395a.svg)

list.title: Question 55
list.content: A function $f(x)$ is defined by $f(x)=\arccos\left(\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2+1}\right)$, $x\in \mathbb{R}$. - Show that $f$ is an even function.[1] - Find the equation of the horizontal asymptote to the graph of $y=f(x)$.[2] - - Show that $f'(x) =- \dfrac{2x}{\sqrt{x^2}\left(x^2+1\right)}$ for $x\in\mathbb{R}$, $x\neq 0$. - Using the expression for $f'(x)$ and the result $\sqrt{x^2}=|x|$, show that $f$ is increasing for $x<0$.[9] A function $g$ is defined by $g(x)=\arccos\left(\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2+1}\right)$, $x\in \mathbb{R}$, $x\geq0$. - Find the range of $g$. [2] - Find an expression for $g^{-1}(x)$. [4] - State the domain of $g^{-1}(x)$. [1] - Sketch the graph of $y=g^{-1}(x)$. Clearly indicating any asymptotes with their equations and stating the values of any axes intercepts.[3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(-x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-x) &= \arccos\left(\dfrac{(-x)^2-1}{(-x)^2+1}\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \arccos\left(\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2+1}\right) \\[12pt]
  &= f(x)\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Therefore, \(f(x)\) is an even function}}$
- Taking the limit as $x$ tends to $\pm \infty$, using the continuity
of the $\arccos$ function, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \to \pm \infty} \arccos\left(\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2+1}\right) &= \arccos\left(\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2+1}\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \arccos\left(\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}\dfrac{1-\dfrac{1}{x^2}\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}}{1+\dfrac{1}{x^2}\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}}\right) \\[10pt]
  &= \arccos(1) \\[16pt]
  &= 0\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Therefore \(y=0\) is a horizontal asymptote for the graph of \(y=f(x)\)}}$
- 
  - If we calculate the derivative of $f$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\bigg[\arccos\left(\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2+1}\right)\bigg] \\[12pt]
    &= -\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2+1}\right)^2}} \left(\dfrac{4x}{\left(x^2+1\right)^2}\right) \hspace{2em} [\text{by chain rule}]\\[12pt] 
    &= -\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(x^2+1\right)^2-\left(x^2-1\right)^2}{\left(x^2+1\right)^2}}} \left(\dfrac{4x}{\left(x^2+1\right)^2}\right)\\[12pt]
    &= -\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{\dfrac{4x^2}{\left(x^2+1\right)^2}}} \left(\dfrac{4x}{\left(x^2+1\right)^2}\right)\\[14pt]
    &= -\dfrac{x^2+1}{2\sqrt{x^2}}\cdot \dfrac{4x}{\left(x^2+1\right)^2}\\[18pt]
    &= -\dfrac{2x}{\sqrt{x^2}\left(x^2+1\right)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - $f$ is increasing when $f'(x)>0$. Using that $\sqrt{x^2}=|x|$,
we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f'(x) &= -\dfrac{2x}{\sqrt{x^2}\left(x^2+1\right)} \\[12pt]
    &= -\dfrac{2x}{|x|\left(x^2+1\right)} \\[12pt]
    &= \left\lbrace\begin{array}{ll} \phantom{-}\dfrac{2}{x^2+1}&x<0 \\[12pt] 
    -\dfrac{2}{x^2+1}&x> 0
    \end{array}\right.\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    $\answer{\text{Therefore \(f\) is increasing over \(x<0\)}}$

- Using G.D.C., we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/40959260-ff44-430d-ba78-56c4196b0ee8/images/739aa0a1-8497-4bf5-9271-580041574b8f/f0c0fbdf08255f11d554923de27f12f77e5813a5.svg)


  Hence,$\answer{\text{range of \(g\)\,:\,} (0,\pi]}$
- If we solve the equation $\left(g\circ g^{-1}\right)(x)=x$ for
$y=g^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g\left(g^{-1}(x)\right) &= x \\[12pt]
  g(y) &= x \\[12pt]
  \arccos\left(\dfrac{y^2-1}{y^2+1}\right) &= x \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{y^2-1}{y^2+1} &= \cos x\\[12pt]
  (y^2+1)\cos x&=y^2-1\\[12pt]
  y^2\cos x-y^2&=-1-\cos x\\[12pt]
  y^2(\cos x-1)&=-1-\cos x\\[12pt]
  y^2&=\dfrac{1+\cos x}{1-\cos x}\\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-2mm}\answer{g^{-1}(x)=\sqrt{\dfrac{1+\cos x}{1-\cos x}}} \hspace{2em} \cos x \neq 1\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{domain of $g^{-1}$} &= \text{range of $g$} \hspace{1.7em} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= (0,\pi]}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using G.D.C., we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/40959260-ff44-430d-ba78-56c4196b0ee8/images/63161565-a004-495b-ba3d-450b387f7d58/5eccef056ae5f9c36509f6f503f953d242605d5c.svg)
